Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Dexmedetomidine and Propofol in Hysteroscopic Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 150 patients aged 18-60 years with ASA status I-II undergoing hysteroscopic surgery

Participants.evidence: 150 patients aged 18-60 years with ASA status I-II undergoing hysteroscopic surgery at the Affiliated Hospital of North Sichuan Medical College

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to receive dexmedetomidine at 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, or 1.0 µg/kg, or saline

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to determine the optimal dose of dexmedetomidine combined with propofol for hysteroscopic surgery

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the EC50 of propofol, measured intraoperatively

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using SPSS software, and allocation was concealed

Blinding.evidence: Both patients and clinicians were blinded

Number_Randomised.evidence: 150 patients aged 18-60 years with ASA status I-II undergoing hysteroscopic surgery

Number_Analysed.evidence: The EC50 of propofol was significantly lower in the Dex 0.6, Dex 0.8, and Dex 1.0 groups compared to the saline group

Result_Outcome.evidence: The EC50 of propofol was significantly lower in the Dex 0.6, Dex 0.8, and Dex 1.0 groups compared to the saline group (p < 0.05)

Harms.evidence: Higher dexmedetomidine doses reduced propofol requirements and respiratory depression incidence (p < 0.01) but increased bradycardia incidence (p = 0.02)
